unnormalised: Alright, folks, let's talk training regimens! Whether you're dreaming of lifting the Ranji Trophy or just want to crush your local 10k, a solid training plan is your best friend. Think of it like your mom's secret recipe for the perfect biryani – it takes time, tweaking, and the right ingredients.
normalised: Alright, folks, let's talk training regimens! Whether you're dreaming of lifting the Ranji Trophy or just want to crush your local ten kilometer, a solid training plan is your best friend. Think of it like your mom's secret recipe for the perfect biryani – it takes time, tweaking, and the right ingredients.

unnormalised: First off, there's no one-size-fits-all. What works for Virat Kohli probably won't work for you, unless you also have his genes and a personal Dr. overseeing your every calorie! Your training needs to be tailored to your sport, your current fitness level, and your goals. If you’re prepping for the kabaddi nationals in Patna, your regimen will be vastly different from someone training for a marathon in Mumbai.

If you’re prepping for the kabaddi nationals in Patna, your regimen will be vastly different from someone training for a marathon in Mumbai.

unnormalised: A good regimen has a few key components. Strength training is crucial, even if you're not trying to look like a bodybuilder. Building muscle helps prevent injuries and improves overall performance. Think squats, lunges, and maybe even some good old-fashioned desi push-ups. Aim for at least 2-3 sessions per week, focusing on compound movements. For example, my friend Rohan, who plays badminton at the state level, spends hours in the gym, strengthening his core and legs to improve his agility on the court. His gym in Delhi is a modest 800 sq ft, but packs a serious punch!

unnormalised: Then there's cardio. Running, swimming, cycling – pick something you enjoy. Interval training is particularly effective for boosting your stamina. Imagine sprints up and down Marine Drive – tough, but rewarding!

unnormalised: Nutrition is the unsung hero. You can train like a beast, but if you’re fueling your body with junk, you're wasting your time. Protein is essential for muscle repair, so load up on those dals and paneer. Listen to your body and adjust your diet accordingly. Consulting a nutritionist can make a world of difference. My cousin Priya, who runs marathons, swears by her diet plan from AIIMS which includes precise amounts of carbs, proteins, and fats. She spends roughly Rs. 5000 per month on supplements and specialized foods.

unnormalised: Rest and recovery are just as important as the training itself. Your muscles need time to rebuild after a tough workout. Aim for at least 7-8 hours of sleep per night. Don't be afraid to take rest days! Overtraining can lead to injuries and burnout.

unnormalised: Finally, track your progress. Keep a training log to monitor your workouts, your diet, and your recovery. This will help you identify what's working and what's not. Remember, consistency is key. Stick to your regimen, make adjustments as needed, and you'll be amazed at what you can achieve. Jai Hind! Now go out there and train hard!
